awd_titl_txt: An Integrated Approach to Early Elementary Earth and Space Science
awd_abstract_narration:
State science standards increasingly emphasize the importance of engaging K-12 students directly in natural phenomena and providing opportunities to construct explanations grounded in evidence. Moreover, these state science standards introduce earth and space science content in the early elementary grades. This creates a critical need for new pedagogies, materials, and resources for science teachers in all grades, but the need is particularly urgent in grades K-3 where teachers have had little preparation to teach science, let alone astronomy. There is also growing consensus that when learning opportunities in formal and informal settings are closely aligned, children's science literacy is developed in ways greater than either setting can achieve alone. The investigators will study if, how, and under what circumstances an integration of literacy strategies, hands-on inquiry-based investigations, and planetarium experiences supports the development of science practices (noticing, recognizing change, making predictions, and constructing explanations) in early elementary level students. This project will generate knowledge about how astronomy-focused storybooks, hands-on investigations, and planetarium experiences can be integrated to develop age-appropriate science practices in very young children (noticing, recognizing change, making predictions, and constructing explanations). This project is funded by the Discovery Research preK-12 program (DRK-12), which seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of STEM by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

Emergent research on the development of children's science thinking indicates that when young children are engaged with science-focused storybooks and activities that each highlight the same phenomenon, children notice and gather evidence, make predictions and claims based on evidence, and provide explanations grounded in the experiences provided to them. This project has two phases. In Phase 1, first and third grade teachers will be recruited. They will help identify specific learner needs as these relate to the earth and space science standards in their grade band, assist in the development and pilot testing of a prototype instructional sequence and supporting activities taking place within their classrooms and at a local planetarium. In Phase 2, the revised learning sequence and research protocol will be implemented with the same teachers and a new cohort of children. The mixed method research design includes video observations, teacher interviews, and teacher and student surveys. Data analysis will focus on science practices, connections across contexts (e.g., school and planetarium), and instructional adaptations. The project involves a research-practice collaboration between the Astronomical Society of the Pacific, Rockman & Associates, the Lawrence Hall of Science [University of California, Berkeley], and West Chester University.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project PLANET: An Integrated Approach to Early Elementary Earth and Space Science, studies if, how, and under what circumstances integrating astronomy-focused storybooks, hands-on investigations, and interactive planetarium experiences supports the development of age-appropriate science practices in elementary school students. Existing research in informal settings demonstrates when young children engage with science-focused storybooks and activities mirroring phenomena in the books, they notice, gather evidence, make evidence-based predictions, and offer explanations grounded in experiences provided to them. This project extends this research to formal learning environments for early elementary children in grades 1 and 3. The Astronomical Society of the Pacific, Rockman et al Cooperative, Lawrence Hall of Science (University of California, Berkeley), and West Chester University conduct the work. 

State instructional standards increasingly stress the development of science practices starting in early elementary grades, which creates a need for new pedagogical approaches, materials, and resources for teachers. Project PLANET?s intellectual merit lies in its exploration of an innovative instructional approach designed to develop scientific practices     in first and third grade students. Specifically, the project explores if and how a lesson sequence consisting of an astronomy-focused storybook, classroom activities, and an interactive planetarium experience engages children in noticing, gathering evidence, and making predictions. The project?s broadest societal impact is in the knowledge generated about how to foster     science practices in children who eventually will become scientifically literate adults who use evidence-based reasoning in their everyday lives. Moreover, because the project involves students in underserved communities and explores the impact of culturally responsive teaching practices on children?s science interest and engagement, findings will help broaden STEM participation. 

The Project PLANET instructional sequence begins with the teacher reading a storybook aloud. In first-grade, children were read Moonbear?s Shadow by Frank Asch. A bear tries to escape its shadow that is scaring fish it tries to catch. Next, children explore how to change the direction and length of a shadow using a flashlight, a figure of a bear, a model tree, and a fabric pond with a fish.  A second reading of the book follows, along with in-class shadow drawing activities that prepare children for a planetarium field trip. In the planetarium, children engage in kinesthetic activities and create shadows on the dome. They also see a figure of a bear casting shadows of differing orientations and lengths depending on the Sun?s position. The planetarium lets students observe changes over the course of a day within minutes, allowing them to notice and predict the pattern of shadows over time without having to wait for the actual Sun to move. The student?s post-planetarium activities include more in-class shadow drawing activities (including drawing shadows cast by the students outside) and the creation of their own shadow stories. The third-grade sequence followed much the same pattern, with reading from the book Breakfast Moon, by Meg Gower. This story follows Mae and Arthur, siblings who observe the Moon on different days, noticing its change in shape and location in the sky.  Mae and Arthur keep a journal of their observation and notice patterns.  Each morning, they choose a breakfast food to match the shape of the Moon they observe. In-class and planetarium activities explore the sequence of lunar phases, with the planetarium experience cycling through a month of moon phases in just a few minutes. Students predict the location and phase of the Moon even when clouds obstruct the view.  As in the book, third graders keep a journal and draw their observations of the actual Moon.

Project PLANET research investigates if and under what conditions (1) the sequences successfully encourage children to notice, recognize change, make predictions, and construct evidence-based explanations, (2) teachers and children connect the learning experiences across the curriculum components, (3) teachers make adaptations to the lessons, and why, and (4) inclusion of culturally responsive teaching practices increases student interest and engagement. Key findings from the project include the following: (1) both first and third grade sequences successfully encouraged children to engage in age-appropriate scientific practices, (2) multiple readings of the storybooks are especially helpful in encouraging children to identify patterns and make connections across the learning sequence they had not noticed before, (3) both formal and informal educators have a critical role in helping children make connections between the elements of the lesson sequences - as well as to children?s cultural and personal experiences - as students do not readily make these connections on their own, and (4) combining formal and informal learning experiences that closely follow the science explorations of a compelling character in a storybook appears to have an impact on developing scientific thinking skills in very young children.
